posts.title: 5 Negative Thought Patterns You Need To Drop Now
posts.markdown: Negative thought patterns can easily turn a good day into an absolutely terrible day, especially for those of us with anxiety.  I try my hardest to avoid any negative thoughts, whether they’re directed at me or at others, because I recognize that thinking negatively affects me on both a physical and emotional level. But it can be hard at times and a lot of us fall into these patterns of negativity without even realizing it.  Here are five negative thought patterns that you should probably get out of your life, and fast: **Catastrophizing** This happens when we perceive a tiny mistake or misfortune in our lives as being the one thing that will ultimately ruin *everything* for us.  Not only does this exaggeration not help us, it fosters anxiety, fear, stress and helplessness.  Don’t believe that the worst has happened before it’s happened. **Generalizing** I think that everyone, somewhere deep inside of them, knows that when they say ‘blanket’ statements that unfairly group individuals together without a second glance, that there’s some element of dishonesty in what they’re saying.  Stating that everything is either ‘this way’ or ‘that way’ is a poor way of viewing the world.  Don’t make it a habit. **Personalizing** As much as we would like to think that we are at the center of the universe, we are not.  The world does not belong to you just as much as it does not belong to me.  Always acknowledge that people will act the way they act because they’re sorting through issues of their own, and that it probably doesn’t have anything to do with you (don’t take things so personally).   **Filtering** Filtering is something that we all do.  Shockingly, people only like to hear things that resonate positively with what they believe or understand.  Try to avoid only hearing what you want to hear.  Take the good with the bad, because if you only have one side of the picture, how you can fully understand it?   **“Should”-ing** Constantly telling yourself that you *should* have done this or *should *have done that is bad for one’s view of him or herself.  The word ‘should’ denotes that we’re incapable or lacking in certain areas.  You’re basically telling yourself you’re not good enough or didn’t do well enough.  If you truly think you *should* be doing something then make the effort to make it happen.  If it’s not worth doing, then don’t bother with it, and certainly don’t stress over it.
posts.html:
Negative thought patterns can easily turn a good day into an absolutely terrible day, especially for those of us with anxiety.  I try my hardest to avoid any negative thoughts, whether they’re directed at me or at others, because I recognize that thinking negatively affects me on both a physical and emotional level.

But it can be hard at times and a lot of us fall into these patterns of negativity without even realizing it.  Here are five negative thought patterns that you should probably get out of your life, and fast:

Catastrophizing

This happens when we perceive a tiny mistake or misfortune in our lives as being the one thing that will ultimately ruin everything for us.  Not only does this exaggeration not help us, it fosters anxiety, fear, stress and helplessness.  Don’t believe that the worst has happened before it’s happened.

Generalizing

I think that everyone, somewhere deep inside of them, knows that when they say ‘blanket’ statements that unfairly group individuals together without a second glance, that there’s some element of dishonesty in what they’re saying.  Stating that everything is either ‘this way’ or ‘that way’ is a poor way of viewing the world.  Don’t make it a habit.

Personalizing

As much as we would like to think that we are at the center of the universe, we are not.  The world does not belong to you just as much as it does not belong to me.  Always acknowledge that people will act the way they act because they’re sorting through issues of their own, and that it probably doesn’t have anything to do with you (don’t take things so personally).  

Filtering

Filtering is something that we all do.  Shockingly, people only like to hear things that resonate positively with what they believe or understand.  Try to avoid only hearing what you want to hear.  Take the good with the bad, because if you only have one side of the picture, how you can fully understand it?  

“Should”-ing

Constantly telling yourself that you should have done this or should have done that is bad for one’s view of him or herself.  The word ‘should’ denotes that we’re incapable or lacking in certain areas.  You’re basically telling yourself you’re not good enough or didn’t do well enough.  If you truly think you should be doing something then make the effort to make it happen.  If it’s not worth doing, then don’t bother with it, and certainly don’t stress over it.

posts.title: Man Attempts To Hug a Wild Lion. What Happens Next Stunned Me!
posts.markdown: It’s always amazing (and terrifying) to get up close and personal with the wild animals that share this world with us.  While most of us will only experience them comfortably from the other side of a glass wall or tall fence, some people have made it their life to not only understand these beasts, but to develop real connections with them. **[South African zookeeper Kevin Richardson](http://www.lionwhisperer.co.za/)** is one such a person. Known as the “Lion Whisperer,” Kevin was able to build and maintain strong bonds with the wild lions living near Pretoria, South Africa.  So much so that they accept him as family.   This deep closeness gives Kevin the opportunity to garner an understanding of them that goes beyond what we typically see; acknowledging each member of the pride for his or her unique behaviors, instincts and emotions. Watch as Kevin demonstrates his connection with these magnificent creatures, even placing his arm in one of their mouths will full confidence that his lion companion will not harm him. Kevin hopes to one day own and operate the Kevin Richardson Wildlife Sanctuary, with the goal of “providing a self-sustaining African carnivore sanctuary for the purposes of wild species preservation through education, awareness and funding, especially pertaining to the rapid decline of large carnivores in Africa due to habitat loss, human-predator conflict, unscrupulous hunting, disease and their illegal trade.”

posts.title: 5 Tips for Raising a ‘Good’ Kid, According to A Harvard Psychologist
posts.markdown: Being a millennial, I grew up in an era where technology was on the cusp of booming into what it has transformed into today.  I played computer games that I found in cereal boxes, I instant messaged my friends using AOL or MSN, and I fell in love with video games and technology in general.  But nowadays, the limits of technology aren’t as prominent as when I was a kid.  While I grew up with *some* technology, what we had was never anything like what the kids of today have.  The iPhone wasn’t a thing until I got to college; I was super proud of my matte black Motorola Razr in high school, it couldn’t do much (relative to smartphones today), but it was awesome. If you walked into a supermarket today and saw a toddler using a tablet or smartphone, you probably wouldn’t even think twice about it.  I know that my spoiled cousins, who are in elementary school, have had the latest in tech gadgetry for as long as they can remember. The invasion of technology into our children’s lives has become a concern for some, acknowledging that they are now having to compete (sometimes fiercely) for their child’s attention in a world full of computer user interface interaction.  And they’re worried that it’s going to affect whether or not their kids turn into ‘good’ kids or ‘bad’ kids. But **[Harvard psychologists have been studying](http://mcc.gse.harvard.edu/)** the things parents do that cause their children to turn out one way or another, and reoccurring themes have popped up everywhere, suggesting that there are still tried-and-true methods of child-rearing that will help your kid become a successful, functioning member of society like we all want them to be. Here are five tips from **[Harvard psychologists](https://www.facebook.com/makingcaringcommon)** for how to raise your child: **Spend time with your kids** Perhaps the most fundamental and useful tip you should take heed of when reading this, spending time with your kids is the most important thing you can do when they’re young.  Ask them questions about their world, how it makes sense to them, and what they think about themselves.  Be sure to really listen and engage with them when you do this, you’ll learn so much about your child, and you’ll be teaching them how to listen to others and care for them. **If something matters, say it out loud** Wanting something for your child is natural, and if it really matters to you then say it out loud to them.  Researchers have said, “even though most parents and caretakers say that their children being caring is a top priority, often children aren’t hearing that message.”  Tell them that you want them to be nice and caring.  And be sure to check in with the adult supervisors that they interact with on a regular basis to see how they’re doing with teamwork and just being a decent being. **Show your child how to solve their problems** The decision-making processes that we all go through on a routine basis have been largely influenced by our parents and the way they did things.  Try going through these processes with them, showing them how to think critically along the way.  For example, if they want to quit the sport they’ve been playing.  Ask them how their decision will affect the other members of the team and whether or not their quitting will help anything. **Exhibit helpfulness and gratitude regularly** The researchers say that “studies show that people who engage in the habit of expressing gratitude are more likely to be helpful, generous, compassionate, and forgiving–and they’re also more likely to be happy and healthy.”  Which means that parents should be holding their kids accountable for chores and their expressions of gratitude throughout their days.  However, researchers have suggested that parents only give praise to “uncommon acts of kindness” when it comes to rewarding ‘positive’ behavior. **Teach them how to see the bigger picture** According to the researchers, “almost all children empathize with and care about a small circle of families and friends,” which means that the key to this tip is being able to get them to care about people who lie outside of these familiar circles.  To do this, teach them how to be excellent listeners, encourage them to try to place themselves in another’s position, and use opportune moments to teach them how to empathize. The final quote of the study says this: “Raising a caring, respectful, ethical child is and always has been hard work. But it’s something all of us can do. And no work is more important or ultimately more rewarding.” h/t [**UpWorthy**](http://www.upworthy.com/harvard-psychologists-have-been-studying-what-it-takes-to-raise-good-kids-here-are-6-tips)
posts.html:
Being a millennial, I grew up in an era where technology was on the cusp of booming into what it has transformed into today.  I played computer games that I found in cereal boxes, I instant messaged my friends using AOL or MSN, and I fell in love with video games and technology in general. 

But nowadays, the limits of technology aren’t as prominent as when I was a kid.  While I grew up with some technology, what we had was never anything like what the kids of today have.  The iPhone wasn’t a thing until I got to college; I was super proud of my matte black Motorola Razr in high school, it couldn’t do much (relative to smartphones today), but it was awesome.

If you walked into a supermarket today and saw a toddler using a tablet or smartphone, you probably wouldn’t even think twice about it.  I know that my spoiled cousins, who are in elementary school, have had the latest in tech gadgetry for as long as they can remember.

The invasion of technology into our children’s lives has become a concern for some, acknowledging that they are now having to compete (sometimes fiercely) for their child’s attention in a world full of computer user interface interaction.  And they’re worried that it’s going to affect whether or not their kids turn into ‘good’ kids or ‘bad’ kids.

But Harvard psychologists have been studying the things parents do that cause their children to turn out one way or another, and reoccurring themes have popped up everywhere, suggesting that there are still tried-and-true methods of child-rearing that will help your kid become a successful, functioning member of society like we all want them to be.

Here are five tips from Harvard psychologists for how to raise your child:

Spend time with your kids

Perhaps the most fundamental and useful tip you should take heed of when reading this, spending time with your kids is the most important thing you can do when they’re young.  Ask them questions about their world, how it makes sense to them, and what they think about themselves.  Be sure to really listen and engage with them when you do this, you’ll learn so much about your child, and you’ll be teaching them how to listen to others and care for them.

If something matters, say it out loud

Wanting something for your child is natural, and if it really matters to you then say it out loud to them.  Researchers have said, “even though most parents and caretakers say that their children being caring is a top priority, often children aren’t hearing that message.”  Tell them that you want them to be nice and caring.  And be sure to check in with the adult supervisors that they interact with on a regular basis to see how they’re doing with teamwork and just being a decent being.

Show your child how to solve their problems

The decision-making processes that we all go through on a routine basis have been largely influenced by our parents and the way they did things.  Try going through these processes with them, showing them how to think critically along the way.  For example, if they want to quit the sport they’ve been playing.  Ask them how their decision will affect the other members of the team and whether or not their quitting will help anything.

Exhibit helpfulness and gratitude regularly

The researchers say that “studies show that people who engage in the habit of expressing gratitude are more likely to be helpful, generous, compassionate, and forgiving–and they’re also more likely to be happy and healthy.”  Which means that parents should be holding their kids accountable for chores and their expressions of gratitude throughout their days.  However, researchers have suggested that parents only give praise to “uncommon acts of kindness” when it comes to rewarding ‘positive’ behavior.

Teach them how to see the bigger picture

According to the researchers, “almost all children empathize with and care about a small circle of families and friends,” which means that the key to this tip is being able to get them to care about people who lie outside of these familiar circles.  To do this, teach them how to be excellent listeners, encourage them to try to place themselves in another’s position, and use opportune moments to teach them how to empathize.

The final quote of the study says this:

“Raising a caring, respectful, ethical child is and always has been hard work. But it’s something all of us can do. And no work is more important or ultimately more rewarding.”

h/t UpWorthy

posts.title: 5 Common Myths About Introverts
posts.markdown: Introverts catch a lot of heat from people who don’t understand their personality type. But there’s a ton of information regarding introverts all over the internet, which is a great thing because many people have introverted tendencies and don’t even know it.  You might even display some yourself. These five myths about introverts highlight the disconnect between how introverts are perceived and how they are in actuality: **Introverts don’t like conversing with others** It might seem like introverts rarely add to the discussion, but that’s because they don’t like to talk just to hear themselves talk.  If they can’t add anything to the conversation, then they’d prefer not to speak at all.  Bring up a subject they’re interested in, however, and prepare to listen to them talk forever. **Introverts are too shy** Introverts’ shy demeanor doesn’t come from a fear of interacting with others, they just lack any motivation to actually start interacting.  If you want to start interacting with the introvert, just begin doing it and they’ll come around eventually. **Introverts are typically rude** An introvert’s perceived rudeness is often the result of their blunt and honest nature.  This is not how the average person operates, which means they usually find themselves struggling to fit in.  They would prefer it if everyone had the same straightforward approach to life. **Introverts want to spend most of their time alone** Yes, the introvert spends a lot of time alone, but that’s only because they enjoy their own company.  They like to work through problems and puzzles, they like to daydream about different realities.  But that doesn’t mean they never crave human connection.  In fact, they long to share their world with others. **Introverts need to be fixed in order to become more extroverted** Please, never think that introverts are flawed in some way and need fixing.  This is their natural demeanor, personality, and temperament.  They connect and interact with the world in *different* ways, not *worse* ways.  There are even studies that show introverted-ness goes up with increases in IQ.
posts.html:
Introverts catch a lot of heat from people who don’t understand their personality type. But there’s a ton of information regarding introverts all over the internet, which is a great thing because many people have introverted tendencies and don’t even know it.  You might even display some yourself.

These five myths about introverts highlight the disconnect between how introverts are perceived and how they are in actuality:

Introverts don’t like conversing with others

It might seem like introverts rarely add to the discussion, but that’s because they don’t like to talk just to hear themselves talk.  If they can’t add anything to the conversation, then they’d prefer not to speak at all.  Bring up a subject they’re interested in, however, and prepare to listen to them talk forever.

Introverts are too shy

Introverts’ shy demeanor doesn’t come from a fear of interacting with others, they just lack any motivation to actually start interacting.  If you want to start interacting with the introvert, just begin doing it and they’ll come around eventually.

Introverts are typically rude

An introvert’s perceived rudeness is often the result of their blunt and honest nature.  This is not how the average person operates, which means they usually find themselves struggling to fit in.  They would prefer it if everyone had the same straightforward approach to life.

Introverts want to spend most of their time alone

Yes, the introvert spends a lot of time alone, but that’s only because they enjoy their own company.  They like to work through problems and puzzles, they like to daydream about different realities.  But that doesn’t mean they never crave human connection.  In fact, they long to share their world with others.

Introverts need to be fixed in order to become more extroverted

Please, never think that introverts are flawed in some way and need fixing.  This is their natural demeanor, personality, and temperament.  They connect and interact with the world in different ways, not worse ways.  There are even studies that show introverted-ness goes up with increases in IQ.

posts.title: This Man Built a 'Dog Train' For Elderly Rescued Dogs, This Video Had Me In Tears!
posts.markdown: Eugene Bostick has about as much time on his hands as I would imagine most retirees have, trading their regular day job for time spent doing hobbies and pursuing other passions.  Officially, Bostick has been retired for around 15 years, but is just now developing this newfound joy for bringing adventure to rescued dogs. Eugene is an 80-year-old Fort Worth, Texas, native.  One who never in a million years thought he would end up spending his “golden years” bringing joy to pets in need.  But it is not something he says happened by his own volition: “We live down on a dead-end street, where me and my brother have a horse barn,” Bostick **[told The Dodo](https://www.thedodo.com/man-builds-dog-train-for-rescued-pups-1362467342.html)**. “People sometimes come by and dump dogs out here, leaving them to starve. So, we started feeding them, letting them in, taking them to the vet to get them spayed and neutered. We made a place for them to live.” ![Man builds train for all his rescued dogs](https://i.imgur.com/jk0CDpul.jpg) Bostick has remained vigilant in his quest to see these dogs taken care of, having rescued too many to count.  But rescuing them wasn’t enough for Bostick, it would seem.  Keeping them happy was also a priority. The dogs of course have plenty of space on Bostick’s farm to run freely and play with one another, but Eugene thought it would be even better if he could find a way to take them to other places, too.  Which is when he came up with the idea for the ‘dog train.’ “One day I was out and I seen this guy with a tractor who attached these carts to pull rocks. I thought, ‘Dang, that would do for a dog train,'” said Bostick. “I’m a pretty good welder, so I took these plastic barrels with holes cut in them, and put wheels under them and tied them together.” One to two times a week, Bostick and the nine dogs he currently cares for, fill the dog train and visit different locales, like the local creek, quiet streets in town, and the forest near Bostick’s home.   “Whenever they hear me hooking the tractor up to it, man, they get so excited,” Bostick said. “They all come running and jump in on their own. They’re ready to go.” “I’m getting up in age. I’m 80 now, so I suppose it can’t last too much longer, but I’ll keep it going as long as I can,” said Eugene. “The dogs have a great time. They just really enjoy it.”
posts.html:
Eugene Bostick has about as much time on his hands as I would imagine most retirees have, trading their regular day job for time spent doing hobbies and pursuing other passions.  Officially, Bostick has been retired for around 15 years, but is just now developing this newfound joy for bringing adventure to rescued dogs.

Eugene is an 80-year-old Fort Worth, Texas, native.  One who never in a million years thought he would end up spending his “golden years” bringing joy to pets in need.  But it is not something he says happened by his own volition:

“We live down on a dead-end street, where me and my brother have a horse barn,” Bostick told The Dodo.

“People sometimes come by and dump dogs out here, leaving them to starve. So, we started feeding them, letting them in, taking them to the vet to get them spayed and neutered. We made a place for them to live.”

Bostick has remained vigilant in his quest to see these dogs taken care of, having rescued too many to count.  But rescuing them wasn’t enough for Bostick, it would seem.  Keeping them happy was also a priority.

The dogs of course have plenty of space on Bostick’s farm to run freely and play with one another, but Eugene thought it would be even better if he could find a way to take them to other places, too.  Which is when he came up with the idea for the ‘dog train.’

“One day I was out and I seen this guy with a tractor who attached these carts to pull rocks. I thought, ‘Dang, that would do for a dog train,'” said Bostick. “I’m a pretty good welder, so I took these plastic barrels with holes cut in them, and put wheels under them and tied them together.”

One to two times a week, Bostick and the nine dogs he currently cares for, fill the dog train and visit different locales, like the local creek, quiet streets in town, and the forest near Bostick’s home.  

“Whenever they hear me hooking the tractor up to it, man, they get so excited,” Bostick said. “They all come running and jump in on their own. They’re ready to go.”

“I’m getting up in age. I’m 80 now, so I suppose it can’t last too much longer, but I’ll keep it going as long as I can,” said Eugene. “The dogs have a great time. They just really enjoy it.”

posts.title: One Major U.S. City Is Requiring All Pet Stores to Sell Only Rescues
posts.markdown: Phoenix, Arizona, joined the **[official list of U.S. cities](http://www.bizjournals.com/phoenix/news/2015/07/31/puppies-n-love-owner-expects-to-appeal-ruling-on.html)** that are working to pass legislation focused on shutting down the operation of puppy mills.  And they’re doing it by **[requiring all pet stores to only offer dogs that have been rescued](https://www.thedodo.com/puppy-mills-take-a-hit-1023432625.html)**. This comes following the **[upholding of a 2013 ordinance](http://www.azcentral.com/story/news/local/phoenix/2015/07/29/phoenix-outlaw-some-pet-sales-commercial-breeders-approved-judge/30861879/)** that banned the sales of puppies and kittens at pet stores, requiring adoption services for rescues and shelter animals instead.   So far, the list that Phoenix joins consists of over **[59 different cities and counties](https://www.thedodo.com/puppy-mills-take-a-hit-1023432625.html)** all over the United States, each one working to pass legislation similar to Phoenix’s. If you’ve never heard of puppy mills, they’re basically businesses that have intense, and often inhumane, breeding practices.  **[Profit from their puppies](https://www.thedodo.com/puppy-mill-doodles-975608564.html)** comes at a price, however, one that is paid in full by the well-being of the puppies themselves, as well as the dogs being used to breed them.   The dogs that breed these puppies are typically **[caged their whole lives](https://www.thedodo.com/rescued-dogs-had-never-even-felt-grass-before-1274048102.html)**; rarely, if ever, receiving love or affection.   Phoenix’s decision is celebrated by groups like the **[Humane Society of the United States](http://www.humanesociety.org/?credit=web_id424367309?referrer=http://www.humanesociety.org/search/search-results.html?q=phoenix)**, alongside a number of pet owners and animal activists who wish to see this practice finished.   While some pet store owners are upset with the legislation, claiming that it will hurt business, it cannot be overlooked that this policy will help prevent the deaths of millions of animals who get euthanized each year, instead of going to a good home. What do you think about this legislation? Do you think people should be buying puppies or adopting rescues? And don’t forget to share with your friends and family!
posts.html:
Phoenix, Arizona, joined the official list of U.S. cities that are working to pass legislation focused on shutting down the operation of puppy mills.  And they’re doing it by requiring all pet stores to only offer dogs that have been rescued.

This comes following the upholding of a 2013 ordinance that banned the sales of puppies and kittens at pet stores, requiring adoption services for rescues and shelter animals instead.  

So far, the list that Phoenix joins consists of over 59 different cities and counties all over the United States, each one working to pass legislation similar to Phoenix’s.

If you’ve never heard of puppy mills, they’re basically businesses that have intense, and often inhumane, breeding practices.  Profit from their puppies comes at a price, however, one that is paid in full by the well-being of the puppies themselves, as well as the dogs being used to breed them.  

The dogs that breed these puppies are typically caged their whole lives; rarely, if ever, receiving love or affection.  

Phoenix’s decision is celebrated by groups like the Humane Society of the United States, alongside a number of pet owners and animal activists who wish to see this practice finished.  

While some pet store owners are upset with the legislation, claiming that it will hurt business, it cannot be overlooked that this policy will help prevent the deaths of millions of animals who get euthanized each year, instead of going to a good home.

What do you think about this legislation? Do you think people should be buying puppies or adopting rescues?

And don’t forget to share with your friends and family!

posts.title: 5 Easy Ways to Create Positive Energy in Your Home
posts.markdown: When does a living space become a home?  After you’ve filled it with the things that are dear to you and the things that make you feel at home.  One of the best things you can do to your home and to the space that you occupy when you’re not running around doing things, is to fill it with positive energy. There are more than a few ways to do this and doing so provides you a plethora of different benefits, including heightened creativity and inspiration, feeling more safe and secure, and elevated levels of harmony in relationships. Check out these five ways to bring that much needed positive energy into your home or living space: **Clean up clutter** There is something to be said about minimalism and having only the things you need.  A lot of the time, we acquire so many different knick-knacks throughout our days and weeks and months that they just get tossed somewhere in the house, left to be forgotten, but still taking up space. Clutter from these things brings about a stagnant energy that can actually attract negative energies.  Which makes you feel unmotivated and sometimes even depressed. If you haven’t used it in a long time or you’re apathetic towards something, get rid of it. **Lighting & Air** Dim lighting can be one’s worst enemy; it slows down the vibration in the room, which can ultimately affect our mood.  Try opening up windows and curtains to let a bit of natural light come in.  Himalayan Salt lamps are great for ridding a space of negative and stagnant energy.  Plants and air purifiers are other great additions to a home to increase air quality. **White Sage** White Sage is notorious for keeping areas of clear of negative energies and unwanted visitors.  It has natural healing properties, helping to calm and sooth.  It effectively creates a barrier, helping one to ignore the stresses of the outside world.  To do this, simply burn the sage while walking around your living space, allowing the smoke to fill your home. **Singing Bowls & Bells** Being 100% vibration, sound is capable of healing and harmonizing a living space.  Singing bowls and bells are a great way to add peaceful sounds to a living space.   These bowls and bells come in a variety of different frequencies and have been said to balance the two hemispheres of the brain, which promotes stress reduction, relaxation, and meditation. **Oils & Incense** Different oils and incense have an amazing effect on your home.  They’re great tools for clearing negative energies and cleansing a space.  For incense, try frankincense, jasmine and sandalwood; these incense are inherently protective and can clear your space of lower energies. When it comes to diffusing oils, you have a few options.  Citrus oils help stimulate motivation and happiness, floral scents help relieve anxiety and promote harmony, and herbal and wooden scents help fight off negative energies.

posts.title: How To Check If the Pavement is Too Hot For Your Dog
posts.markdown: Every good dog owner probably has the basics of pup safety down when it comes to surviving the summer heat.  Things like bringing lots of water with you wherever you go, looking for **[signs that they’re overheating](https://www.thedodo.com/how-to-tell-dog-overheating-1224088290.html)**, and never ever leaving them in the car, are common knowledge. But even some of the most caring and loving of owners forget that the ground itself can be incredibly hot, sometimes so hot that it can cause quite a bit of suffering for your pup and his or her feet. ![](https://scontent-yyz1-1.xx.fbcdn.net/v/t1.0-0/p403x403/13331152_1093673134044659_2165758981826158917_n.jpg?oh=f46f4b94423bc94affda1089bfab71ee&oe=582B4825) And you undoubtedly know what it feels like.  Remember as a kid, walking onto the hot pavement of your street or the hot sand of the beach and thinking, “Wow, this really hurts. I’m going to not walk on this anymore.”  It’s the same thing your dog is thinking. “Asphalt gets very hot and can burn your pet’s paws, so walk your dog on the grass if possible,” the **[Humane Society of the United States](http://www.humanesociety.org/animals/resources/tips/pets_safe_heat_wave.html)** says. However, sometimes it can be hard to tell.  So, **[Moon Valley Canine Training ](https://www.facebook.com/pages/Moon-Valley-Canine-Training/185614088146445)**has come up with a quick and easy test to help you determine whether or not your dog is safe walking on a hot surface: Place the back of your hand on the pavement and try to hold it there for at least five seconds, if you can’t do this, then the surface is too hot for your pup to walk on safely. If the pavement is indeed too hot, wait until the heat has subsided a bit to take them on a walk, or make them stay on grass.  If walking on the hot pavement is something that cannot be avoided, test out **[other protection methods](http://petslady.com/articles/10_tips_protect_your_dogs_paws_hot_pavement_57624)**, like dog booties or special wax designed to coat their paws, protecting them from heat. You can learn more about how to keep your dogs safe and happy this summer here.  And don’t forget to share with friends and family who might need a quick reminder of dog safety! h/t [**The Dodo**](https://www.thedodo.com/how-to-tell-if-the-pavement-is-too-hot-for-your-dogs-feet-1242363093.html)
posts.html:
Every good dog owner probably has the basics of pup safety down when it comes to surviving the summer heat.  Things like bringing lots of water with you wherever you go, looking for signs that they’re overheating, and never ever leaving them in the car, are common knowledge.

But even some of the most caring and loving of owners forget that the ground itself can be incredibly hot, sometimes so hot that it can cause quite a bit of suffering for your pup and his or her feet.

And you undoubtedly know what it feels like.  Remember as a kid, walking onto the hot pavement of your street or the hot sand of the beach and thinking, “Wow, this really hurts. I’m going to not walk on this anymore.”  It’s the same thing your dog is thinking.

“Asphalt gets very hot and can burn your pet’s paws, so walk your dog on the grass if possible,” the Humane Society of the United States says.

However, sometimes it can be hard to tell.  So, Moon Valley Canine Training has come up with a quick and easy test to help you determine whether or not your dog is safe walking on a hot surface:

Place the back of your hand on the pavement and try to hold it there for at least five seconds, if you can’t do this, then the surface is too hot for your pup to walk on safely.

If the pavement is indeed too hot, wait until the heat has subsided a bit to take them on a walk, or make them stay on grass.  If walking on the hot pavement is something that cannot be avoided, test out other protection methods, like dog booties or special wax designed to coat their paws, protecting them from heat.

You can learn more about how to keep your dogs safe and happy this summer here.  And don’t forget to share with friends and family who might need a quick reminder of dog safety!

h/t The Dodo

posts.title: Which Psychic Gift is Strongest In You?
posts.markdown: All of us possess some level of psychic ability, whether we’re aware of it or not.  Maybe you’ve noticed that you have a subtle way of picking up on things before they happen or you’re a master at figuring out people’s true motives, or maybe you’re just really good at knowing when not to do something.   These are all signs that your psychic ability is in good health. The four most common psychic intuitions are: clairvoyance (seeing), clairaudience (hearing), clairsentience (feeling), and claircognizance (knowing). You’re probably gifted in all of these areas, but there is likely just one that is your strongest and most proficient.   Clairsentience and claircognizance tend to be the most heightened among people, but you can try these exercises to figure exactly which one you exhibit most: **To test your ‘clairvoyance’** Close your eyes and try to picture how your body appears as it is now.  For example, I’m sitting on my couch.  I’d try to think to think about as much detail as I could about how I exist right now.   Am I sitting down?  What kind of clothes do I have on?  Do I look happy, sad or indifferent?  The more crystal clear you can make this picture of yourself, the more clairvoyant you are said to be. **To test your ‘clairaudience’** Close your eyes again, but this time focus solely on all of the different noises and sounds that fill the air around you.  Then, slowly work to eliminate each sound from your head until you find the silence that lies underneath all of the sound.   Once you’ve found this low, universal vibration, listen to your heart beating and the sound of your lungs working.  This can take days to achieve, but if you can, then you are likely clairaudient. **To test ‘clairsentience’** This test requires that you take a photograph of a person that you do not personally know, but whom someone close to you knows.  Practice analyzing all of the different feelings and emotions you get when you look at the picture of this person.   Do you feel like you can trust them?  What kind of person do you think they are?  Good or bad, write down your thoughts and then discuss them with your friend.   If you find that your predictions or thoughts about the person were accurate or significant, you are probably clairsentient. **To test ‘claircognizance’** This exercise requires you to look inward, asking for guidance and direction from your higher being.  Once you’ve asked for this guidance, start by writing down a question onto the piece of paper.   Then start jotting down whatever thoughts begin flowing through your mind.  Simply write down the words as they come to you; try not to think about what the words or thoughts mean, simply let your thoughts flow and write them down as they come. If you remain consistent with this exercise, your claircognizant ability will eventually become quite prominent, and if you begin to receive messages that are specific or that seem important to you at that time, then you’re likely very claircognizant. h/t [**Disclose.TV**](http://www.disclose.tv/news/we_all_have_psychic_gifts_which_one_is_your_strongest/129522)
posts.html:
All of us possess some level of psychic ability, whether we’re aware of it or not.  Maybe you’ve noticed that you have a subtle way of picking up on things before they happen or you’re a master at figuring out people’s true motives, or maybe you’re just really good at knowing when not to do something.  

These are all signs that your psychic ability is in good health.

The four most common psychic intuitions are: clairvoyance (seeing), clairaudience (hearing), clairsentience (feeling), and claircognizance (knowing).

You’re probably gifted in all of these areas, but there is likely just one that is your strongest and most proficient.  

Clairsentience and claircognizance tend to be the most heightened among people, but you can try these exercises to figure exactly which one you exhibit most:

To test your ‘clairvoyance’

Close your eyes and try to picture how your body appears as it is now.  For example, I’m sitting on my couch.  I’d try to think to think about as much detail as I could about how I exist right now.  

Am I sitting down?  What kind of clothes do I have on?  Do I look happy, sad or indifferent?  The more crystal clear you can make this picture of yourself, the more clairvoyant you are said to be.

To test your ‘clairaudience’

Close your eyes again, but this time focus solely on all of the different noises and sounds that fill the air around you.  Then, slowly work to eliminate each sound from your head until you find the silence that lies underneath all of the sound.  

Once you’ve found this low, universal vibration, listen to your heart beating and the sound of your lungs working.  This can take days to achieve, but if you can, then you are likely clairaudient.

To test ‘clairsentience’

This test requires that you take a photograph of a person that you do not personally know, but whom someone close to you knows.  Practice analyzing all of the different feelings and emotions you get when you look at the picture of this person.  

Do you feel like you can trust them?  What kind of person do you think they are?  Good or bad, write down your thoughts and then discuss them with your friend.  

If you find that your predictions or thoughts about the person were accurate or significant, you are probably clairsentient.

To test ‘claircognizance’

This exercise requires you to look inward, asking for guidance and direction from your higher being.  Once you’ve asked for this guidance, start by writing down a question onto the piece of paper.  

Then start jotting down whatever thoughts begin flowing through your mind.  Simply write down the words as they come to you; try not to think about what the words or thoughts mean, simply let your thoughts flow and write them down as they come.

If you remain consistent with this exercise, your claircognizant ability will eventually become quite prominent, and if you begin to receive messages that are specific or that seem important to you at that time, then you’re likely very claircognizant.

h/t Disclose.TV

posts.title: 6 Helpful Tips for the Empath and Highly Sensitive People
posts.markdown: An empath is a person who has heightened senses, often feeling and experiencing the world around them much more intensely than your average person.  They pick up on the energies and auras of others, often capable of feeling their thoughts and emotions. However, many empaths aren’t even aware that they are empaths at all.  They might recognize their ability to feel others’ energies, but aren’t sure how it works.  Because regularly perceiving and mirroring other people’s energies correctly is difficult.  And there can be negative side effects for empaths who do not know how to control their gift properly. Here are six tips for the empath and the highly sensitive that will help prevent becoming overwhelmed: **Always make time for you** While some people are quite afraid of being alone, spending time with yourself is necessary to create the space one needs to let go of their emotion, energy and stresses. **Speak positively, think positively** Using positive affirmations to build positive thought patterns is a great practice for the empath.  Phrases like “Let me receive what is in my best and highest good at this time,” will help manifest positivity. **Learning to shield** One of the best ways to prevent yourself from being overwhelmed is by creating a protective shield of white light around you.  Tie it down with a grounding cord and you’re prepared to deflect any unwanted energies. **Center yourself** When you leave behind the ego in order to become more in line with your spirit, you’re more capable of living in the moment, feeling free to express and release each emotion as it arises. **Being in nature** Spending time in nature and with animals is the perfect way to clear unwanted energies and connect with the world around you. **Gratitude and Intentions** Some people like to keep a journal to write down all of the things they are grateful for, which promotes a clean, healthy energy.  To keep this energy flowing, they also write down positive intentions to do so.
posts.html:
An empath is a person who has heightened senses, often feeling and experiencing the world around them much more intensely than your average person.  They pick up on the energies and auras of others, often capable of feeling their thoughts and emotions.

However, many empaths aren’t even aware that they are empaths at all.  They might recognize their ability to feel others’ energies, but aren’t sure how it works.  Because regularly perceiving and mirroring other people’s energies correctly is difficult.  And there can be negative side effects for empaths who do not know how to control their gift properly.

Here are six tips for the empath and the highly sensitive that will help prevent becoming overwhelmed:

Always make time for you

While some people are quite afraid of being alone, spending time with yourself is necessary to create the space one needs to let go of their emotion, energy and stresses.

Speak positively, think positively

Using positive affirmations to build positive thought patterns is a great practice for the empath.  Phrases like “Let me receive what is in my best and highest good at this time,” will help manifest positivity.

Learning to shield

One of the best ways to prevent yourself from being overwhelmed is by creating a protective shield of white light around you.  Tie it down with a grounding cord and you’re prepared to deflect any unwanted energies.

Center yourself

When you leave behind the ego in order to become more in line with your spirit, you’re more capable of living in the moment, feeling free to express and release each emotion as it arises.

Being in nature

Spending time in nature and with animals is the perfect way to clear unwanted energies and connect with the world around you.

Gratitude and Intentions

Some people like to keep a journal to write down all of the things they are grateful for, which promotes a clean, healthy energy.  To keep this energy flowing, they also write down positive intentions to do so.

posts.title: 6 Things To Start Doing For Yourself. #4 Is Absolutely Vital.
posts.markdown: If life has you down in the dumps and you can’t seem to figure out how to get back on track, these six life tips might just do the trick.  Don’t get down on your luck; figure out what’s wrong and then work hard to fix it.  You create the reality you live in. Here are six things you need to start doing for yourself right now: **Spend your time with the ones who matter** Life is too short to keep negative or toxic people in your world.  Instead, focus on the ones who you like being with, the ones who love you for who you are and who encourage your growth.  These are the people who not only love who you are, but support who you want to be. **Face life’s challenges and problems head on** Everyone has problems in their life, but our reactions and behaviors concerning them are what truly define us.  As I’m sure you know, problems don’t simply go away when they are ignored.  So, do your best right now, even if its only baby steps, to overcome the obstacles in your life.   Eventually these small steps you take every day will add up in the long run. **Be brutally honest with yourself** One of the biggest obstacles in finding happiness or success is being afraid to admit the reality of your situation.  Always be completely honest with yourself when it comes to what is wrong and what has to change.  At the end of the day, you are the only person you can count on.   Recognize where you are now and how you ended up here, then you can start to move toward where you want to go. **Recognize that your happiness is just as important as other’s** Many of us get so caught up in being the generous, caring individuals that we are, that we sometimes forget that we have our own needs and desires that need to be fulfilled.  Always place value on *you*.   Remember, you can help those around you even better if you take the time to make yourself happy first. **Be a genuine and proud version of yourself** The best part about being you is that no one else in the world can do *you* as good as you do.  Don’t waste any time on trying to be like others.  Embrace every aspect of who you are; your ideas, strengths, weaknesses, flaws, talents, everything.   You know you have endless potential, so be the best version of yourself that you can be. **View each mistake as a lesson to be learned** So many people are afraid of failure.  What they do not understand is that we learn the *most* from failing.  Mistakes are fine, everyone will make plenty of them in their lifetime.  If you’re not making mistakes, you’re not truly living. Always be open to taking risks, knowing that should you fail, you have the ability to get up, shake it off and try again.  Your mistakes are the pathway to success.
posts.html:
If life has you down in the dumps and you can’t seem to figure out how to get back on track, these six life tips might just do the trick.  Don’t get down on your luck; figure out what’s wrong and then work hard to fix it.  You create the reality you live in.

Here are six things you need to start doing for yourself right now:

Spend your time with the ones who matter

Life is too short to keep negative or toxic people in your world.  Instead, focus on the ones who you like being with, the ones who love you for who you are and who encourage your growth.  These are the people who not only love who you are, but support who you want to be.

Face life’s challenges and problems head on

Everyone has problems in their life, but our reactions and behaviors concerning them are what truly define us.  As I’m sure you know, problems don’t simply go away when they are ignored.  So, do your best right now, even if its only baby steps, to overcome the obstacles in your life.  

Eventually these small steps you take every day will add up in the long run.

Be brutally honest with yourself

One of the biggest obstacles in finding happiness or success is being afraid to admit the reality of your situation.  Always be completely honest with yourself when it comes to what is wrong and what has to change.  At the end of the day, you are the only person you can count on.  

Recognize where you are now and how you ended up here, then you can start to move toward where you want to go.

Recognize that your happiness is just as important as other’s

Many of us get so caught up in being the generous, caring individuals that we are, that we sometimes forget that we have our own needs and desires that need to be fulfilled.  Always place value on you.  

Remember, you can help those around you even better if you take the time to make yourself happy first.

Be a genuine and proud version of yourself

The best part about being you is that no one else in the world can do you as good as you do.  Don’t waste any time on trying to be like others.  Embrace every aspect of who you are; your ideas, strengths, weaknesses, flaws, talents, everything.  

You know you have endless potential, so be the best version of yourself that you can be.

View each mistake as a lesson to be learned

So many people are afraid of failure.  What they do not understand is that we learn the most from failing.  Mistakes are fine, everyone will make plenty of them in their lifetime.  If you’re not making mistakes, you’re not truly living.

Always be open to taking risks, knowing that should you fail, you have the ability to get up, shake it off and try again.  Your mistakes are the pathway to success.

posts.title: What You Never Knew About Giraffes Is Going to Make You Cry
posts.markdown: Giraffes are one of the most widely recognizable animals on the planet due to their long necks and somewhat goofy looking, but adorable faces.  Their iconic status in Africa is well known, but **[new research](http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/aje.12220/epdf)** is showing that they might be in trouble.   All over the continent, giraffes are disappearing in great numbers. Since the year 1998, there has been a massive 43 percent decrease in population, leaving about 80,000 of the creatures to graze across 21 African nations, highlights the study. What’s actually causing such a dramatic decline in their numbers can be attributed to a number of things, including habitat loss, human-wildlife conflicts, and poaching and slashing.   It is worse in different regions of the continent, like in the Democratic Republic of Congo, where giraffes are close to being “locally” extinct with only 30 or 40 giraffes alive in the country, says Stephanie Fennessy, program director with the **[Giraffe Conservation Foundation](http://www.giraffeconservation.org/)**(GCF). “The perception is that giraffe numbers are huge. And that they are everywhere. And there’s no need to protect them,” Fennessy told The Dodo. This perception is slowly starting to become realized as false, and now time is no longer on their side.  One sort of ‘silver lining’ to these animals being researched, however, is that scientists are continuing to learn more about the giraffe’s capacity for emotion, and are weeding out old myths in the process. Zoe Muller, founder of the **[Rothschild’s Giraffe Project](http://www.girafferesearch.com/)**, says, “Ask any safari guide in Africa about their behavior and they will delight in telling you how female giraffe are bad mothers, apparently abandoning their young hours after giving birth and leaving them alone and vulnerable in the African bush.” A notion that Muller has found to be untrue.  One giraffe that she followed during her research gave birth to a calf in the spring of 2010.  At around one month of age and suffering from a deformed leg, the calf struggled to walk and rarely moved because of it.  But the mother giraffe never left its side. “[S]he could always be found next to her calf, standing with it and being vigilant to the surrounding area,” Muller wrote. Unfortunately, the baby calf passed away one morning, most likely due to natural causes.  But, shortly after, Muller discovered 17 other female giraffes “all highly vigilant and running around in apparently bizarre patterns.” While Muller is reluctant to categorize their behavior as “mourning,” she acknowledges that it is similar to another mammal that is notorious for their grieving of lost loved ones: elephants.   “It is well documented that elephants show great interest in the carcasses and bones of other dead elephants and herd members, often viewed as evidence of their empathic nature and ability to ‘mourn’ their dead,” she says. “…we are only just beginning to understand the complexities of their social systems and family networks. This incident provides us a unique insight into one aspect of giraffe behavior that we are rarely afforded a glance of — that of family ties and effects of the loss of a herd member.” You can watch a video of the incident **[here](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=8bI20ZglxOI)**, and below is video of a mother giraffe who took on a pride of lions after they took her calf, showcasing the female giraffe’s willingness to endure danger for the sake of their young. h/t [**The Dodo**](https://www.thedodo.com/giraffe-mothers-conservation-1170369798.html)
posts.html:
Giraffes are one of the most widely recognizable animals on the planet due to their long necks and somewhat goofy looking, but adorable faces.  Their iconic status in Africa is well known, but new research is showing that they might be in trouble.  

All over the continent, giraffes are disappearing in great numbers.

Since the year 1998, there has been a massive 43 percent decrease in population, leaving about 80,000 of the creatures to graze across 21 African nations, highlights the study.

What’s actually causing such a dramatic decline in their numbers can be attributed to a number of things, including habitat loss, human-wildlife conflicts, and poaching and slashing.  

It is worse in different regions of the continent, like in the Democratic Republic of Congo, where giraffes are close to being “locally” extinct with only 30 or 40 giraffes alive in the country, says Stephanie Fennessy, program director with the Giraffe Conservation Foundation(GCF).

“The perception is that giraffe numbers are huge. And that they are everywhere. And there’s no need to protect them,” Fennessy told The Dodo.

This perception is slowly starting to become realized as false, and now time is no longer on their side.  One sort of ‘silver lining’ to these animals being researched, however, is that scientists are continuing to learn more about the giraffe’s capacity for emotion, and are weeding out old myths in the process.

Zoe Muller, founder of the Rothschild’s Giraffe Project, says, “Ask any safari guide in Africa about their behavior and they will delight in telling you how female giraffe are bad mothers, apparently abandoning their young hours after giving birth and leaving them alone and vulnerable in the African bush.”

A notion that Muller has found to be untrue.  One giraffe that she followed during her research gave birth to a calf in the spring of 2010.  At around one month of age and suffering from a deformed leg, the calf struggled to walk and rarely moved because of it.  But the mother giraffe never left its side.

“[S]he could always be found next to her calf, standing with it and being vigilant to the surrounding area,” Muller wrote.

Unfortunately, the baby calf passed away one morning, most likely due to natural causes.  But, shortly after, Muller discovered 17 other female giraffes “all highly vigilant and running around in apparently bizarre patterns.”

While Muller is reluctant to categorize their behavior as “mourning,” she acknowledges that it is similar to another mammal that is notorious for their grieving of lost loved ones: elephants.  

“It is well documented that elephants show great interest in the carcasses and bones of other dead elephants and herd members, often viewed as evidence of their empathic nature and ability to ‘mourn’ their dead,” she says.

“…we are only just beginning to understand the complexities of their social systems and family networks. This incident provides us a unique insight into one aspect of giraffe behavior that we are rarely afforded a glance of — that of family ties and effects of the loss of a herd member.”

You can watch a video of the incident here, and below is video of a mother giraffe who took on a pride of lions after they took her calf, showcasing the female giraffe’s willingness to endure danger for the sake of their young.

h/t The Dodo

posts.title: They Found This Cat Neglected In A Shed, His Transformation Will Leave You In Tears!
posts.markdown: With a growing number of cities working on legislation that would make it illegal for pet stores to sell anything other than rescued animals, their timing couldn’t be more perfect.   Animals with stories like Orren’s, the beautiful black kitty who was rescued from a shed, are becoming increasingly common. Neglected for quite some time, Orren had damaged skin all over his body, including a mangled ear, and was struggling to breathe when **[Humane Society](http://www.humanesociety.org/)**workers found him.  But after some fresh air and lots of TLC, Orren made an incredible recovery. The ASPCA (**[American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals](http://www.aspca.org/about-us)**) reports that about **[41 percent of cats](http://www.aspca.org/animal-homelessness/shelter-intake-and-surrender/pet-statistics)** that come into shelters have to be put down.  And they estimate that, in the United States, the number of stray cats is almost 70 million. If you’re in the market for a new pet, whatever type of pet it may be, think about adoption first.  Rescues aren’t dysfunctional problem children, they’re perfectly good companions who need a human that will love them as much as they will love their human.
posts.html:
With a growing number of cities working on legislation that would make it illegal for pet stores to sell anything other than rescued animals, their timing couldn’t be more perfect.  

Animals with stories like Orren’s, the beautiful black kitty who was rescued from a shed, are becoming increasingly common.

Neglected for quite some time, Orren had damaged skin all over his body, including a mangled ear, and was struggling to breathe when Humane Societyworkers found him.  But after some fresh air and lots of TLC, Orren made an incredible recovery.

The ASPCA (American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals) reports that about 41 percent of cats that come into shelters have to be put down.  And they estimate that, in the United States, the number of stray cats is almost 70 million.

If you’re in the market for a new pet, whatever type of pet it may be, think about adoption first.  Rescues aren’t dysfunctional problem children, they’re perfectly good companions who need a human that will love them as much as they will love their human.

posts.title: 5 Side Effects of Meditation to Watch Out For
posts.markdown: Meditation is often viewed by those who have never tried it as a bunch of mumbo-jumbo spiritual non-sense, but that notion could not be further from the truth.  Meditation goes much deeper than simple relaxation, it actually provides a number of health benefits for the body and the mind. And the best part is that it’s entirely free and anyone can learn how to do it. Here are five positive things one can gain by practicing meditation regularly: **Lasting control over your emotions** Meditation brings us down to a calmed state while we’re practicing it, and it’s been seen that this calmed state actually stays with us after we’ve finished meditating.   One study **[scanned the brains of people before and after an 8-week meditation course](http://dx.doi.org/10.3389/fnhum.2012.00292)**, finding reduced activation of the amygdala (the center of emotion in the brain) across all pictures, suggesting meditation benefits exist far after the act of meditation is over. **Increased compassion and virtue** To test the compassion of meditators, a study used actors to see which participants would come to the aid of a person appearing to be in pain.  One actor would come into the staged waiting room on crutches, grimacing in pain, while two other actors sat idly by ignoring the person in pain, so as to give off social cues that no one should intervene. Participants who had been meditating **[were found to be 50 percent more likely](http://dx.doi.org/10.1177/0956797613485603)** to help the person in pain. **It changes the brain structure, in a good way** Eight weeks is all it takes for meditation to manipulate the brain’s structure. One study **[looked at the images of 16 people’s brains](http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.pscychresns.2010.08.006)**before and after they participated in a meditation program.   When compared to the control group, subjects experienced an increase in grey-matter density in the area of the brain responsible for learning and memory. **It promotes creativity** If you’ve been struggling to solve a problem for quite sometime and have run out of answers, try meditating on it.  One study had participants **[come up with as many uses for a brick](http://dx.doi.org/10.3389/fpsyg.2012.00116)**as they could, a traditional creativity task.   Participants who practiced an ‘open monitoring’ meditation technique were able to think up the most uses for the brick.  This type of meditation technique uses focus on one’s breathing to open up the mind. **Greater ability to concentrate** When you look at the fundamentals of meditation, concentration is at the core of it: the ability to **[control your brain’s attention](http://www.spring.org.uk/2009/03/the-attentional-spotlight.php)**.  Numerous studies have found that meditation provides a number of benefits for concentration and attention.   One study had 17 people who had never meditated in their lives take an 8-week course **[on mindfulness-based stress reduction meditation](http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/17672382)**to monitor its effects.  When compared to the control group, these 17 people exhibited heightened levels of concentration and greater ability to focus their attention.
posts.html:
Meditation is often viewed by those who have never tried it as a bunch of mumbo-jumbo spiritual non-sense, but that notion could not be further from the truth.  Meditation goes much deeper than simple relaxation, it actually provides a number of health benefits for the body and the mind.

And the best part is that it’s entirely free and anyone can learn how to do it.

Here are five positive things one can gain by practicing meditation regularly:

Lasting control over your emotions

Meditation brings us down to a calmed state while we’re practicing it, and it’s been seen that this calmed state actually stays with us after we’ve finished meditating.  

One study scanned the brains of people before and after an 8-week meditation course, finding reduced activation of the amygdala (the center of emotion in the brain) across all pictures, suggesting meditation benefits exist far after the act of meditation is over.

Increased compassion and virtue

To test the compassion of meditators, a study used actors to see which participants would come to the aid of a person appearing to be in pain.  One actor would come into the staged waiting room on crutches, grimacing in pain, while two other actors sat idly by ignoring the person in pain, so as to give off social cues that no one should intervene.

Participants who had been meditating were found to be 50 percent more likely to help the person in pain.

It changes the brain structure, in a good way

Eight weeks is all it takes for meditation to manipulate the brain’s structure. One study looked at the images of 16 people’s brainsbefore and after they participated in a meditation program.  

When compared to the control group, subjects experienced an increase in grey-matter density in the area of the brain responsible for learning and memory.

It promotes creativity

If you’ve been struggling to solve a problem for quite sometime and have run out of answers, try meditating on it.  One study had participants come up with as many uses for a brickas they could, a traditional creativity task.  

Participants who practiced an ‘open monitoring’ meditation technique were able to think up the most uses for the brick.  This type of meditation technique uses focus on one’s breathing to open up the mind.

Greater ability to concentrate

When you look at the fundamentals of meditation, concentration is at the core of it: the ability to control your brain’s attention.  Numerous studies have found that meditation provides a number of benefits for concentration and attention.  

One study had 17 people who had never meditated in their lives take an 8-week course on mindfulness-based stress reduction meditationto monitor its effects.  When compared to the control group, these 17 people exhibited heightened levels of concentration and greater ability to focus their attention.

posts.title: Baby Goat Was Abandoned On the Streets, Watch What Happens When She Sees Her New Owner!
posts.markdown: Sometimes life throws us a curveball, testing our emotions and capacity for love.  This baby goat, who was given the name ‘Harley,’ was abandoned by its previous owners and found wandering city streets.  The good samaritan who stumbled across precious Harley took her to animal control, but after some time, she was never claimed. So, the same people who found her decided to take her to **[Hooves & Paws Animal Rescue](http://www.hoovesandpaws.org/)** in Little Rock, California.  Of course the folks at Hooves & Paws were delighted to see an adorable baby goat join their community of other rescued animals. Co-founder of Hooves & Paws, Michele, attempted to contact Harley’s original owners, but they weren’t interested in her.  Harley’s ear tag means that she was likely headed to the slaughterhouse. But, all of this turned out to be quite fortunate for the little goat, who now lives with a loving family, happy as can be! Don’t forget to share with friends and family who would love to see baby Harley’s touching story!

posts.title: 5 Ways to Protect Yourself from Psychic Attacks
posts.markdown: For the past couple of days I’d been having these crazy bouts of insecurity, confusion and sadness, and I could not for the life of me understand why.  I’d been quite happy and carefree the week before, so why the sudden despair and feelings of uncertainty?  As it would turn out, my girlfriend had been stressing out immensely, thinking about the upcoming changes in both of our lives.   I was unknowingly picking up on all of the energy and negativity that she was feeling, and because much of it revolved around me and our relationship, she was unknowingly directing all of that negative energy at me.  When this happens, the person being sent the energy often cannot tell the difference between their own natural thoughts and these thoughts that are being sent to them, which causes even more confusion. Oftentimes people are unknowingly psychically attacking someone, while other times they can be doing it on purpose.  It’s important to recognize when you’re being attacked and what you can do to stop it. Here are five tips for deflecting psychic attacks: **Ask for help from friends, healers and mentors** If you’re not sure where your negative energies, thoughts and feelings are coming from, it can be helpful for your friends and family to bring you into their positive thoughts and feelings.  Don’t be afraid to ask them to think about you during their prayers, meditations and healing practices. **Channel your thoughts elsewhere** This might take some time, but you will ultimately learn to do it.  Whenever you find yourself vulnerable, thinking negative and poisonous things about yourself, a thing or a person, try focusing those thoughts on something constructive or useful. Having a list of goals or positive things you wish for in your life is helpful when picking out something to channel your energy to. **Focus on the good things in your life** Psychic attacks often focus on the vulnerabilities that you have, seeking to exploit the darkness inside of you.  When you feel this happening, take yourself to the happy moments of your life and spend some time in the light. **Stay consistent with healthy habits and rituals** Psychic attacks also work by throwing off your balance.  Losing that balance in your life makes it easier for negativity and darkness to overcome the positivity.   Fortify your balance by keeping consistent with the different aspects of your life, like sleep, diet, exercise and self-reflection. **Try not to retaliate** When people attack you they are opening themselves up to vulnerability.  While our energies have no limits, our attention is finite.   When you spend more time focusing your attention on attacking someone else, you are effectively taking away the attention that you should be spending on yourself, working to create the healthy world that you want.
posts.html:
For the past couple of days I’d been having these crazy bouts of insecurity, confusion and sadness, and I could not for the life of me understand why.  I’d been quite happy and carefree the week before, so why the sudden despair and feelings of uncertainty?  As it would turn out, my girlfriend had been stressing out immensely, thinking about the upcoming changes in both of our lives.  

I was unknowingly picking up on all of the energy and negativity that she was feeling, and because much of it revolved around me and our relationship, she was unknowingly directing all of that negative energy at me.  When this happens, the person being sent the energy often cannot tell the difference between their own natural thoughts and these thoughts that are being sent to them, which causes even more confusion.

Oftentimes people are unknowingly psychically attacking someone, while other times they can be doing it on purpose.  It’s important to recognize when you’re being attacked and what you can do to stop it.

Here are five tips for deflecting psychic attacks:

Ask for help from friends, healers and mentors

If you’re not sure where your negative energies, thoughts and feelings are coming from, it can be helpful for your friends and family to bring you into their positive thoughts and feelings.  Don’t be afraid to ask them to think about you during their prayers, meditations and healing practices.

Channel your thoughts elsewhere

This might take some time, but you will ultimately learn to do it.  Whenever you find yourself vulnerable, thinking negative and poisonous things about yourself, a thing or a person, try focusing those thoughts on something constructive or useful.

Having a list of goals or positive things you wish for in your life is helpful when picking out something to channel your energy to.

Focus on the good things in your life

Psychic attacks often focus on the vulnerabilities that you have, seeking to exploit the darkness inside of you.  When you feel this happening, take yourself to the happy moments of your life and spend some time in the light.

Stay consistent with healthy habits and rituals

Psychic attacks also work by throwing off your balance.  Losing that balance in your life makes it easier for negativity and darkness to overcome the positivity.  

Fortify your balance by keeping consistent with the different aspects of your life, like sleep, diet, exercise and self-reflection.

Try not to retaliate

When people attack you they are opening themselves up to vulnerability.  While our energies have no limits, our attention is finite.  

When you spend more time focusing your attention on attacking someone else, you are effectively taking away the attention that you should be spending on yourself, working to create the healthy world that you want.

posts.title: Watch This Family of Elephants Save a Calf From Being Swept Away in the River
posts.markdown: Powerful moving bodies of water are nothing to be taken lightly.  Attempting to cross a river that’s rolling and raging at high speeds will carry away even the most heavy of objects, like busses and cars, or in this case, a baby elephant. This six month old elephant calf was trying to cross a river with the rest of its herd when it lost its footing and was swept down stream.  The [Ewaso Ng’iro river](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ewaso_Ng'iro), in Kenya, was in full force after receiving a healthy dose of rain, but the baby calf’s family wasn’t about to let the river claim their young one. [Watch this family’s daring rescue](http://youtu.be/p9pekF3bV6w) of their young calf, as filmed by tourist Sand Gelderman, and don’t forget to share with friends and family! h/t [Kicheche Camps](https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCsX-g_cJK19FvNofdK9LEKQ)
posts.html:
Powerful moving bodies of water are nothing to be taken lightly.  Attempting to cross a river that’s rolling and raging at high speeds will carry away even the most heavy of objects, like busses and cars, or in this case, a baby elephant.

This six month old elephant calf was trying to cross a river with the rest of its herd when it lost its footing and was swept down stream.  The Ewaso Ng’iro river, in Kenya, was in full force after receiving a healthy dose of rain, but the baby calf’s family wasn’t about to let the river claim their young one.

Watch this family’s daring rescue of their young calf, as filmed by tourist Sand Gelderman, and don’t forget to share with friends and family!

h/t Kicheche Camps
